doc.field: Repatriation of Kosovo refugees under way

German states started repatriating Kosovo refugees. A first group of 160 out of a total of 15,000 refugees started homeward from Muenster/Osnabrueck airport. They received DM 450.00 per capita and are mainly flown to Pristina and Prizren, which are considered safe areas.
Number of part-time workers in drastic decline

Following the new rules for "DM 630 jobs", the number of part-time workers in retail trade and hotels and restaurants dropped dramatically. According to the federal statistics office 1.7 million remained working part-time in these areas in April, a drop of 106,000 against March. In the same monthly comparison, full-time jobs increased by a mere 0.1%. Statisticians hold that this is directly related to the new rules for marginal employment.
Schroeder on his way to Ukraine

Chancellor Schroeder started a trip to Ukraine this afternoon. He wants to dissuade the Ukrainian government from building two nuclear power plants. The seven Western industrial nations offered Ukraine a 10 digit credit for the complete shutdown of the ill-fated Czernobyl plant. SPD and the Greens want to build coal and natural gas driven power plants instead of nuclear ones.
EU commission prepares court action against federal government

According to FDP sources, the EU commission will go to court against the federal government's decision to freeze plans for building an ICE line between Nuremberg and Erfurt. The FDP's traffic expert Karl-Heinz Guttmacher said the EU was preparing the action because Brussels considers the freeze to infringe a former German pledge of building this line as part of the EU high speed net. A total of DM 1.3 billion has been invested in the plan, one third of which came out of EU development funds.
Bavarian state parliament to vote on biannual budget

In their last session before the summer recess, the Bavarian state parliament is to vote on the biannual budget for 1999/2000. The draft provides for additional spending of DM 800 million for the current year, attaining a total expenditure of DM 62.8 billion.

According to Bonn's telecommunications and mail control board, telecommunication attained sales of DM 1.6 billion during the past year. This puts the telecommunications industry in the same league with the automotive industry where economic importance is concerned. It is hoped that this boom will in time increase job openings.

Persons who do not earn enough to raise their kids will have to take on a second job to increase their income. This was decided by the Schleswig-Holstein superior court in judging the case of a warehouse worker earning DM 1,800 net. To assure the DM 600.00 minimum support for each of his 2 children he must work an additional 2-3 hours a week. The situation is different if he receives unemployment compensation. According to the court he will not have to do additional work because any income would be deducted from his compensation.

A nationwide survey showed that employees increasingly compensate overtime with off hours. The survey was made on a request by North Rhine-Westphalia's ministry for labor. More than 4,000 employees from all parts of the country were interviewed between January and April. 56% of the employees had worked overtime, an increase of roughly 10% over the last survey 4 years ago. But for the first time, more persons took their compensation in off hours instead of pay.
